plant_catalog.description: The 'Swiss Cheese Plant' is famous for its natural leaf holes (fenestrations). A fast-growing climber that brings an instant tropical jungle vibe to any room.

care_guide.light: Bright, indirect light. Can tolerate medium light.
care_guide.water: Water every 1-2 weeks, allowing soil to dry out between waterings.
care_guide.humidity: Prefers high humidity but tolerates normal home conditions.

toxicity.warning: Toxic to cats and dogs if ingested.

instructions: Locate a node (a bump on the stem where a leaf or aerial root grows).
Cut just below the node with clean shears.
Place the cutting in water or moist soil.
Wait for roots to develop (2-4 weeks) before potting.

plant_catalog.description: The ultimate survivor. Known for its upright, sword-like leaves and architectural look. It is one of the few plants that converts CO2 to Oxygen at night.

care_guide.light: Thrives in any light, from low shade to direct sun.
care_guide.water: Water every 3-4 weeks. Let soil completely dry.

instructions: Cut a healthy leaf near the base.
Let the cut end callus over for 1-2 days.
Place the leaf in water or soil (ensure the correct end is down).
Roots will form in 4-8 weeks.

plant_catalog.description: A spiky succulent revered for thousands of years for its medicinal gel. A must-have for sunny windowsills.

care_guide.water: Deep water every 3 weeks. Drought tolerant.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Harvest lower leaf, scoop gel, mix with Vitamin E oil for a face mask.
instructions: Cut a mature leaf from the base of the plant.
Wash the leaf and let the yellow sap drain out for 10 minutes (it can be irritating).
Slice off the spiky edges and peel the top skin.
Scoop out the clear gel with a spoon.
Blend the gel with honey and Vitamin E oil until smooth.
Apply to face for 15-20 minutes then rinse with cool water.
tips: Perform a patch test on your wrist before applying to your face.
Store excess gel in an airtight container in the fridge.
skincare_potential.warnings: The yellow latex layer just under the skin can be irritating. Ensure it is drained or washed off.

instructions: Look for small 'pups' growing at the base of the mother plant.
Gently remove the soil around the pup to find its roots.
Cut the pup away from the main plant, keeping some roots attached.
Let the cut dry for a day, then plant in succulent mix.

plant_catalog.description: The design world's darling. Known for its massive, violin-shaped leaves. It can be finicky and hates being moved once settled.

care_guide.water: Water when top 2 inches of soil are dry.

plant_catalog.description: Elegant dark green leaves with white 'spathe' flowers. Famous for dramatically drooping when thirsty, making it easy to understand.

care_guide.water: Keep soil consistently moist but not soggy.

plant_catalog.description: A classic hanging plant that produces adorable 'spiderettes' or pups that can be easily propagated. Very adaptable.

toxicity.warning: Safe for pets (cats may find it hallucinogenic/fun to eat).

plant_catalog.description: With waxy, shiny leaves that look artificial, the ZZ plant stores water in potato-like rhizomes under the soil. Extremely drought tolerant.

care_guide.water: Water only when fully dry (every 3-4 weeks).

plant_catalog.description: A vigorous trailing vine with lobed leaves. Excellent for hanging baskets or training up a trellis.

care_guide.light: Medium to bright light. Avoid direct hot sun.
care_guide.water: Allow topsoil to dry out slightly.

plant_catalog.description: A bold statement plant with thick, glossy, dark green (or burgundy) leaves. It can be finicky and hates being moved once settled.

care_guide.water: Keep moist in summer, reduce in winter.

plant_catalog.description: Famous for its calming fragrance and purple blooms. Difficult to grow indoors unless you have a very sunny spot.

care_guide.water: Deep watering, then let dry completely.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Steep dried buds in hot water for a facial steam.
instructions: Bring water to a boil and pour into a large heat-proof bowl.
Add the dried lavender buds to the water.
Lean over the bowl with a towel draped over your head to trap the steam.
Steam your face for 5-10 minutes.
Rinse with cool water and pat dry.
tips: Cleanse your face before steaming for best results.
Do not get too close to the water to avoid burns.
skincare_potential.warnings: Use caution with hot water. Not recommended for extremely sensitive skin or rosacea.

plant_catalog.description: A classic fern with arching, feathery fronds. It loves moisture and is often found in bathrooms.

care_guide.water: Keep soil constantly moist. Never let dry out.

plant_catalog.description: A long-living succulent that looks like a miniature tree. In some cultures, it is believed to bring good luck and fortune.

care_guide.light: Direct morning sun or bright indirect light.

plant_catalog.description: Golden Pothos is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.
Areca Palm is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.
Basil is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Boil leaves, cool, and use as a facial toner.
instructions: Wash basil leaves thoroughly.
Boil water and pour over the basil leaves in a bowl.
Let it steep until the water cools completely.
Strain the leaves and pour the liquid into a spray bottle or jar.
Add witch hazel if using.
Apply with a cotton pad after cleansing.
tips: Use organic basil to avoid pesticides.
Great for refreshing skin on hot days.
skincare_potential.warnings: Discard if it smells off or becomes cloudy.

plant_catalog.description: Meyer Lemon Tree is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.

skincare_potential.benefits: Exfoliating, brightening, rich in Vitamin C.
skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Mix zest and juice with sugar and olive oil for a body scrub.
instructions: Zest the lemon into a bowl.
Add sugar and olive oil.
Mix well until it forms a gritty paste.
Gently massage onto damp skin in the shower.
Rinse off with warm water.
tips: Avoid using on broken or irritated skin.
Lemon oil can make surfaces slippery, be careful in the shower.
skincare_potential.warnings: Photosensitive: Avoid direct sun exposure immediately after use as citrus can increase sun sensitivity.

plant_catalog.description: String of Pearls is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.
Bird of Paradise is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.
Calathea Orbifolia is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.
Geranium is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Steam face with leaves or infuse oil for a balancing serum.
instructions: Bruise the geranium leaves to release oils.
Place leaves in a jar and cover with jojoba oil.
Let it sit in a sunny spot for 2 weeks, shaking daily.
Strain the oil and transfer to a dropper bottle.
Apply 2-3 drops to face at night.
tips: Ensure leaves are completely dry after washing before adding to oil to prevent mold.
Can also be used as a spot treatment.
skincare_potential.warnings: Patch test first. Essential oils can be potent.

plant_catalog.description: Heartleaf Philodendron is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.
Pilea (Chinese Money Plant) is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.
Rosemary is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.

skincare_potential.benefits: Stimulates hair growth, anti-dandruff, clarifies scalp.
skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Boil sprigs in water, cool, and use as a final hair rinse.
instructions: Bring water to a boil.
Add rosemary sprigs and reduce heat to simmer for 15 minutes.
Turn off heat and let it steep until cool.
Strain the liquid and stir in apple cider vinegar.
Pour over hair after shampooing and conditioning. Do not rinse out.
tips: Can darken blonde hair over time.

Petunia is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.

Mint is a wonderful plant suitable for various environments.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Crush leaves and mix with yogurt for a cooling face mask.
instructions: Crush mint leaves in a mortar and pestle to release juices.
Mix the crushed mint with yogurt and honey.
Apply to clean face, avoiding eye area.
Leave on for 10-15 minutes.
Rinse with cool water.
tips: Great for sunburns or hot days.
Peppermint can be strong, start with less if sensitive.
skincare_potential.warnings: Avoid eye area strictly, mint can sting eyes.

A gentle herb with daisy-like flowers, known for its calming properties.

toxicity.warning: Toxic to pets in large amounts.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Steep flowers for a calming tea compress.
instructions: Steep flowers in hot water for 10 minutes.
Strain and let cool to a comfortable warm temperature.
Soak a clean cloth in the tea.
Apply to face as a compress for 10 minutes.
skincare_potential.warnings: Ensure tea is not too hot.

plant_catalog.description: Bright orange flowers known as 'Pot Marigold', famous for healing skin.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Infuse dried petals in oil for a healing salve.
instructions: Infuse petals in oil for 2 weeks in a sunny spot.
Strain the oil.
Melt beeswax and mix with the oil.
Pour into a tin and let set.
tips: Use for cuts, scrapes, and dry patches.
skincare_potential.warnings: Do not use on deep open wounds.

plant_catalog.description: A refreshing vine plant producing crisp fruits.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Slice for eye pads or blend for a cooling mask.
instructions: Slice cucumber thinly.
Place slices over eyes for 10 minutes.
Alternatively, blend and mix with aloe gel for a mask.

plant_catalog.description: A small tree famous for its potent essential oil.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Dilute oil for a spot treatment.
instructions: Mix 1 drop of tea tree oil with 1 tsp carrier oil.
Dab onto blemishes with a cotton swab.
skincare_potential.warnings: Can cause chemical burns if undiluted.

plant_catalog.description: Aromatic tree known for respiratory relief.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Hang branches in shower for steam inhalation.
instructions: Tie branches together.
Hang from shower head (not in direct water flow).
Shower as usual and inhale the steam.

plant_catalog.description: Fragrant climbing vine with white flowers.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Infuse flowers in oil for a body oil.
instructions: Fill jar with flowers and cover with oil.
Infuse for 2 weeks.
Strain and use as body oil.
tips: Pick flowers in the evening for strongest scent.
Keep oil out of direct sun.

plant_catalog.description: Tropical shrub with large, colorful flowers. Known as 'Nature's Botox'.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Grind dried petals into a powder for a mask.
instructions: Grind petals to a fine powder.
Mix with honey and yogurt.
Apply to face for 10 mins.
Rinse gently.

plant_catalog.description: The 'Village Pharmacy' tree, known for powerful medicinal properties.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Make a paste from leaves for acne.
instructions: Mix powder with water to form a paste.
Apply to acne spots or full face.
Let dry and rinse.

plant_catalog.description: Rhizomatous plant with beautiful flowers, famous for its golden spice.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Mix powder with yogurt for a glow mask.
instructions: Mix all ingredients.
Apply to face.
Leave for 10-15 mins.
Rinse well.
skincare_potential.warnings: Do not leave on too long or you will turn yellow.

plant_catalog.description: Aromatic herb with grey-green leaves.

skincare_potential.diy_recipe: Brew as a toner for oily skin.
instructions: Steep sage in hot water.
Cool and strain.
Apply with cotton pad.

plant_catalog.description: Low-growing herb with tiny leaves and strong scent.

instructions: Steep thyme in witch hazel for 2 weeks.
Strain.
Use as spot treatment.
tips: More effective than benzoyl peroxide in some studies.

plant_catalog.description: Lemon-scented herb from the mint family.

instructions: Brew strong tea.
Cool.
Apply as compress.
